verses.text: After this, Nahash the king of the Ammonites died, and his son became king in his place.
verses.comment: Closely follows the original Hebrew; 'After this' clarifies temporal sequence.

verses.text: David said, 'I will show kindness to Hanun the son of Nahash, because his father showed kindness to me.' So David sent messengers to console him concerning his father. And David's servants came to Hanun in the land of the Ammonites to comfort him.
verses.comment: Represents David's intent and the consolatory mission; 'comfort him' reflects the original intent.

verses.text: But the princes of the Ammonites said to Hanun, 'Do you think David is honoring your father by sending you comforters? Have not his servants come to you to search the city, spy it out, and overthrow it?'
verses.comment: 'Comforters' preserves the Hebrew nuance; 'search the city' matches original suspicion.

verses.text: So Hanun took David's servants and shaved them, and cut off their garments at the hips, and sent them away.
verses.comment: 'Shaved them' and 'cut off their garments at the hips' maintain literal translation and historical meaning.

verses.text: Then some people went and told David about the men, and he sent messengers to meet them, for the men were greatly ashamed. And the king said, 'Stay at Jericho until your beards have grown back, and then return.'
verses.comment: Follows original; identifies location and David's compassionate response.

verses.text: When the Ammonites saw that they had become a stench to David, Hanun and the Ammonites sent one thousand talents of silver to hire chariots and horsemen from Aram Naharaim, Aram Maacah, and Zobah.
verses.comment: 'A stench to David' renders the idiom meaning 'offensive/enemies.' Region names use modern conventions.

verses.text: So they hired thirty-two thousand chariots, and the king of Maacah with his army, who came and camped before Medeba. And the Ammonites gathered together from their cities and came out to battle.
verses.comment: Numbers are rendered directly from Hebrew. Location names preserve historical geography.

verses.text: When David heard of it, he sent Joab and all the army of mighty men.
verses.comment: 'Mighty men' accurately translates the Hebrew 'the warriors.'

verses.text: And the Ammonites came out and lined up for battle at the entrance of the city, while the kings who had come were by themselves in the open country.
verses.comment: Geographical details maintain the original military disposition.

verses.text: When Joab saw that the battle was set against him from both the front and the rear, he chose from all the best soldiers of Israel and arranged them to face the Arameans.
verses.comment: 'Arameans' reflects Hebrew; 'set against him' clarifies the two-front threat.

verses.text: He put the rest of the army under the command of Abishai his brother, and they drew up to face the Ammonites.
verses.comment: Maintains clear narrative division of command.

verses.text: And he said, 'If the Arameans are too strong for me, then you must help me; but if the Ammonites are too strong for you, then I will help you.'
verses.comment: Dialogue presented directly as in Hebrew; mutual aid kept explicit.

verses.text: 'Be strong, and let us fight bravely for our people and the cities of our God, and may the LORD do what seems good to him.'
verses.comment: 'Let us fight bravely' spells out the Hebrew phrase; final clause preserves theological nuance.

verses.text: So Joab and the people who were with him approached the Arameans for battle, and they fled before him.
verses.comment: 'Approached for battle' clarifies the action; 'fled' preserves original verb.

verses.text: And when the Ammonites saw that the Arameans had fled, they also fled before Abishai his brother, and went into the city. Then Joab returned to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Sequence kept direct, including the movement into the city.

verses.text: But when the Arameans saw that they had been defeated by Israel, they sent messengers and brought out the Arameans who were beyond the Euphrates River, with Shophach the commander of the army of Hadadezer leading them.
verses.comment: 'Beyond the Euphrates' modernizes 'beyond the river.' Name rendered per Hebrew; 'Shophach' sometimes spelled 'Shobach.'

verses.text: When David was told of this, he gathered all Israel, crossed the Jordan, came upon them, and arranged his forces against them. And when David had prepared for battle against the Arameans, they fought with him.
verses.comment: David's direct leadership made explicit per Hebrew wording.

verses.text: And the Arameans fled before Israel, and David killed seven thousand charioteers and forty thousand horsemen, and also Shophach, the commander of the army.
verses.comment: Numbers directly translated; some manuscripts read 'charioteers' or 'horsemen.'

verses.text: And when the servants of Hadadezer saw that they were defeated by Israel, they made peace with David and became his servants. So the Arameans were not willing to help the Ammonites anymore.
verses.comment: 'Servants' here means vassals. Final sentence preserves original cause-and-effect conclusion.
